Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrating Random Energy into the Smart Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The Smart Grid is among the most important and ambitious engineering endeavors of our time. Deep integration of renewable electricity generation is a key driver of the Smart Grid vision. A fundamental challenge is that these energy sources are highly variable ? they are not dispatchable, experience large and rapid changes, and are difficult to predict. The electricity grid must absorb this variability through a portfolio of solutions that include improved forecasts, demand shaping, electricity storage, optimal grid operations, and new market instruments. Our objective is to analyze this portfolio for wind energy integration. We will develop an analytical framework to study how wind variability can be addressed in competitive electricity markets at deep penetration levels. We will investigate market based wind curtailment, aggregation, matching of variable generation and flexible loads, and novel contract instruments.

Broader Impact
The societal impact of our research comes from the fact that renewable electricity generation is critical for energy security and environmental sustainability. Our research directly addresses the obstacles that must be overcome to significantly increase the penetration of renewable generation. The technological impact of our research will stem from our novel framework to analyze existing options and design novel mechanisms for renewable integration. This will offer new insights and analysis methods which will guide the design of optimal portfolios of technology components and coordination mechanisms. The educational impact of our research is derived from our serious efforts at integrating education at all levels with our research. We will equip our students with the multi-disciplinary training in power systems operations, optimization, control, and economics to become leaders in making the Smart Grid vision a reality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are at the dawn of a global commitment to a sustainable energy future. Renewable energy (wind and solar) is an essential component of this future. The critical difficulty with these renewable generation sources is that their production is random. In current practice, reserve generation is used to balance random renewable supply. At deep penetration levels of renewables, this approach is economically untenable and defeats the sustainability benefits of renewables.  Also, renewable generators receive generous subsidies in the form of feed-in tariffs and other credits. Under political and competitive pressures these subsidies are disappearing, and renewables will have to sell their production through electricity markets on par with other market participants. Conventional electricity markets consist of (a) day-ahead bulk power markets where electricity is traded in one hour blocks based on supply and demand forecasts made 24 hours in advance of delivery, and (b) real-time markets where power is traded in 5 minute blocks, 30 minutes in advance of deliver to realize fine balance of supply and demand. Further imbalances are dealt with through ancillary services such as frequency regulation and automatic generation control.

The broad objective of this project is to explore the nuanced problem of selling random renewable energy. The four principal findings of this project are:

  1. We conducted an economic analysis of how wind power producers might participate in existing settlement wholesale electricity markets without subsidy. We obtain closed form expressions for optimal wind producer bids in the day-ahead market, their resulting average profit, and the quantity of their random production that is brought to market.
  2. Using this analysis, we studied the economic benefits of aggregating the power from wind farms. We show that wind farms as a collective can exploit negative correlations in their production to reliably sell more of their renewable generation. We devised mechanisms for fairly sharing profits of the collective, and showed that these schemes incentivize wind farms to form stable coalitions.
  3. We next argued that introducing intermediate markets (say 4 or 6 hours ahead of delivery) offer a viable means for increasing the penetration of renewables. Such an intermediate market offers random renewable generators greater visibility into their production at delivery time, resulting in more accurate forecast and efficient bids. We have developed a general theory of risk-limiting-dispatch (RLD) that accounts for multiple recourse opportunities to adjust the quantity of renewables sold, and we have shown that RLD enables deeper renewable penetration.

Flexible demand offers a zero-emissions alternative to balancing the random supply from renewables. Consumers are encouraged to use more electricity when it is plentiful, and less when it is scarce. We have shown that the aggregate flexibility of collections of electric vehicles and residential AC systems can be approximately modeled as a stochastic battery. The battery parameters depend of exogenous processes such as temperature or occupancy. Using this simple battery model, we have devised control and scheduling algorithms that enable system operators to reliably use flexible demand as a balancing resource for random renewables.
